Subject: Re: [neat] Re: Another note on activation
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=7192225; y=qI0zWLLYTKc314KpRkbzd3Zs0Tm8qyGGelgQRTZjxg-LBaZUhQ

Hi,
	One aspect to iterative propagation that I didn't see mentioned yet 
is the question of variable time-delays on different paths through a network.

	Suppose we are evolving a controller and we have only a single 
output, nets with different paths of different lengths will bring the 
signals from one "frame" of input to the output at different 
times.  In many problems this cannot be correct.  So this adds a 
constraint that the evolution must encompass, possibly only with difficulty.

	HOWEVER, one aspect to biological system that might mitigate this, 
and which most ANN implementations do not attempt to reproduce, is 
that biological systems are not purely step-wise.

	e.g. the inside of a single ANN neurone might do something like this:

Output = ActivationFunction(LastSum);
LastSum = Sum(Inputs, Weights);

	The unbiological aspect to this is that it is totally stepwise, 
there is no leakage of state from LastSum in frame N to LastSum in 
frame N + 1.  Biological systems have this leakage in both +ve and -ve forms:

+ve - the triggering (biological activation is all or nothing) of a 
neuron is an integration over time, say:

Output = ActivationFunction(LastSum);
LastSum = (Sum(Inputs, Weights) + LastSum) / 2.0;		// or adjust the 
rate of decay to suit yourself, or evolve it

-ve - biological neurons have a "refactory period" after firing 
during which they cannot fire again, thus:

Output = Output * 0.9 + ActivationFunction(LastSum, Output) * 0.1;	// 
second input to ActivationFunction is inhibitory
LastSum = Sum(Inputs, Weights);

	The first of these has the effect of making processing a 
time-average, which could smooth out minor differences in signal 
travel times.  The latter allows saturated systems to continue 
functioning (as does down-regulation, another bio-feature we don't 
tend to use) but to some extent we get that by using a sigmoid 
instead of a all or nothing.

	Note that a standard recurrent NEAT implementation can achieve the 
first case all on its own, whoever, with a single recurrent link from 
a neuron's output back to its input.

	Ian
